elements.content: The T d point group symmetry of rare earth (RE3+) metal clusters RE4(μ3-OH)4(COO)6 2+ makes them attractive building blocks for creating metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) with controllable topologies. Herein, we describe the design and synthesis of a series of isoreticular MOFs featuring pcu topology [MOF-1114­(RE) and MOF-1115­(RE)] with variable rare earth metal ions (RE3+ = Y3+, Sm3+, Eu3+, Gd3+, Tb3+, Dy3+, Ho3+, Er3+, Tm3+, Yb3+) and linear amino-functionalized dicarboxylate linkers of different lengths. In total, we report 22 MOFs that vary in both composition and structure yet share the same RE4(μ3-OH)4 cluster motif. We demonstrate that these pcu MOFs are cationic and that anion exchange can be used to affect the MOF properties. We also investigate the luminescence properties of a representative member of this MOF series [MOF-1114­(Yb)] that exhibits near-infrared emission. We show that the excitation energy for Yb3+ sensitization can be carefully adjusted to lower energy via covalent postsynthetic modification at the amino group sites within the MOF.
elements.clean_text: The T d  point group symmetry of rare earth (RE3+) metal clusters RE4(μ3-OH)4(COO)6 2+ makes them attractive building blocks for creating metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with controllable topologies. Herein, we describe the design and synthesis of a series of isoreticular MOFs featuring pcu topology [MOF-1114(RE) and MOF-1115(RE)] with variable rare earth metal ions (RE3+ = Y3+, Sm3+, Eu3+, Gd3+, Tb3+, Dy3+, Ho3+, Er3+, Tm3+, Yb3+) and linear amino-functionalized dicarboxylate linkers of different lengths. In total, we report 22 MOFs that vary in both composition and structure yet share the same RE4(μ3-OH)4 cluster motif. We demonstrate that these pcu MOFs are cationic and that anion exchange can be used to affect the MOF properties. We also investigate the luminescence properties of a representative member of this MOF series [MOF-1114(Yb)] that exhibits near-infrared emission. We show that the excitation energy for Yb3+ sensitization can be carefully adjusted to lower energy via covalent postsynthetic modification at the amino group sites within the MOF.

elements.content: We have a long-standing interest in creating rare earth (RE3+)-based emissive materials, with a focus on tuning their excitation properties for optical biological imaging applications. RE3+ emitters have several inherent features that make them attractive for biological imaging: (i) sharp, nonoverlapping emission bands that range from the visible to the near-infrared (NIR); (ii) long luminescence lifetimes that allow for temporal discrimination from background autofluorescence, which leads to enhanced signal-to-noise ratios and improved sensitivity of detection; (iii) continuous, stable emission signals that are highly resistant to photobleaching; and (iv) the positions of their emission bands, based on atomic f → f transitions, are independent of solution or environmental conditions, such as pH, solvent, etc. However, f → f transitions are Laporte forbidden, causing direct excitation to be prohibitively inefficient. Further, overtones of C–H, O–H, and N–H vibrations from solvent or other neighboring molecules can quench RE3+ emission. To overcome these challenges, RE3+ excited states must be indirectly sensitized by appropriate chromophores that have large molar absorption coefficients and are capable of converting the excitation light into energy to feed the electronic structures of RE3+. This process is called the “antenna effect”. Many examples of classical molecular antennae are typically coordinated to the RE3+, providing efficient sensitization and protection to the RE3+ from sources of nonradiative deactivation. For biological imaging applications, especially in vivo, it is crucial that the antennae absorb low energy visible or NIR light: biological tissues possess low autofluorescence and have much lower absorption in this region known as the biological window (650–1450 nm), which allows for enhanced sensitivity of detection and deeper penetration of the excitation radiation.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

We have a long-standing interest in creating rare earth (RE3+)-based emissive materials, with a focus on tuning their excitation properties for optical biological imaging applications. RE3+ emitters have several inherent features that make them attractive for biological imaging: (i) sharp, nonoverlapping emission bands that range from the visible to the near-infrared (NIR); (ii) long luminescence lifetimes that allow for temporal discrimination from background autofluorescence, which leads to enhanced signal-to-noise ratios and improved sensitivity of detection; (iii) continuous, stable emission signals that are highly resistant to photobleaching; and (iv) the positions of their emission bands, based on atomic f → f transitions, are independent of solution or environmental conditions, such as pH, solvent, etc. However, f → f transitions are Laporte forbidden, causing direct excitation to be prohibitively inefficient. Further, overtones of C-H, O-H, and N-H vibrations from solvent or other neighboring molecules can quench RE3+ emission. To overcome these challenges, RE3+ excited states must be indirectly sensitized by appropriate chromophores that have large molar absorption coefficients and are capable of converting the excitation light into energy to feed the electronic structures of RE3+. This process is called the "antenna effect". Many examples of classical molecular antennae are typically coordinated to the RE3+, providing efficient sensitization and protection to the RE3+ from sources of nonradiative deactivation. For biological imaging applications, especially in vivo, it is crucial that the antennae absorb low energy visible or NIR light: biological tissues possess low autofluorescence and have much lower absorption in this region known as the biological window (650-1450 nm), which allows for enhanced sensitivity of detection and deeper penetration of the excitation radiation.

elements.content: RE3+-based metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are highly promising for biological imaging applications. RE3+-MOFs can be designed to incorporate a high density of both chromophoric ligands and RE3+, which renders them sufficiently bright. Further, different RE3+ can be incorporated into a single MOF, enabling the creation of luminescent “barcoded” materials that would be uniquely attractive for multiplex measurements. To date, we have prepared numerous NIR-emitting MOFs and shown for the first time that they can be used for biological imaging in living cells. Having demonstrated the applicability of NIR-emitting RE3+-MOFs, we are now motivated to design RE3+-MOF platform materials that will allow for systematic control over structure and careful optimization of photophysical properties. In particular, an ideal MOF platform would accommodate a wide range of RE3+, would be easily postsynthetically modified to tune the RE3+ environment and the photophysical properties, and would serve as the basis for myriad structure–property studies.

elements.content: Salient features of prototypical MOF platforms include: (i) high symmetry and predictable topology imparted by rigid, well-defined secondary building units (SBUs); (ii) ease of structural modification and formation of isoreticular analogues by employing different metal and ligand precursors; and (iii) amenability to functionalization. Multiple MOF platforms have been developed using transition metal ion-based SBUs, including Zn4O­(COO)6- and Zr6(OH)4O4(COO) n -based MOFs. While numerous RE3+-based MOFs have been reported and studied, RE3+-based platforms suitable for systematic modification and study are scarce, with notable exceptions, despite the presence of many well-defined discrete RE3+-carboxylate clusters in the literature. RE4(μ3-OH)4(COO)6 2+ clusters exhibiting the RE4(μ3-OH)4 cubane-like core () are particularly attractive building blocks due to their symmetry, connectivity, and similarity to the ubiquitous Zn4O­(COO)6 SBU. Like Zn4O­(COO)6, RE4(μ3-OH)4(COO)6 2+ can be viewed as an octahedral SBU which can theoretically lead to a wide variety of network topologies through rational design. For example, connecting RE4(μ3-OH)4(COO)6 2+ with linear linkers should afford the pcu net (). However, it has been difficult to carefully control carboxylate coordination to the RE4(μ3-OH)4 core, in part because the RE3+ can accommodate varying numbers of carboxylate ligands and coordinating solvent molecules. Further, syntheses are dependent on solvent, temperature, and pH, as well as on the nature of carboxylate ligands employed. Although a few MOFs containing RE4(μ3-OH)4(ligand) n clusters have been discovered, constructing a MOF platform through deliberate and predictable formation of the RE4(μ3-OH)4(COO)6 2+ cluster has not been achieved to date.

elements.content: Herein, we present the rational design and synthesis of a new porous pcu MOF platform based on the RE4(μ3-OH)4(COO)6 2+ cluster. We determine strategies for constructing an isoreticular family of MOFs based on this SBU and present, in total, 22 new MOF materials with varying structures and compositions. Finally, we demonstrate that these materials are amenable to postsynthetic modification (PSM) via both ion exchange and covalent chemistry. In one representative example, we show for the first time that covalent PSM can be used to systematically optimize the photophysical properties of an Yb3+-based MOF in this series. More specifically, we shift the excitation wavelengths of this MOF toward lower energy in order to create more biologically adapted luminescent probes that would possess excitation and emission wavelengths within the biological window.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we present the rational design and synthesis of a new porous pcu MOF platform based on the RE4(μ3-OH)4(COO)6 2+ cluster. We determine strategies for constructing an isoreticular family of MOFs based on this SBU and present, in total, 22 new MOF materials with varying structures and compositions. Finally, we demonstrate that these materials are amenable to postsynthetic modification (PSM) via both ion exchange and covalent chemistry. In one representative example, we show for the first time that covalent PSM can be used to systematically optimize the photophysical properties of an Yb3+-based MOF in this series. More specifically, we shift the excitation wavelengths of this MOF toward lower energy in order to create more biologically adapted luminescent probes that would possess excitation and emission wavelengths within the biological window.

elements.content: Formation of RE4(μ3-OH)4-related complexes relies on well-controlled hydrolysis or alcoholysis of RE3+ where both solution conditions and suitable supporting ligands play essential roles. Several studies have reported the formation and crystallization of various complexes with RE4(μ3-OH)4 cores from aqueous or alcoholic solutions in the presence of a variety of α-amino acids as supporting ligands. In these examples, the α-amino groups in proximity to the coordinating carboxylates may play an important role in regulating the RE3+ hydrolysis/alcoholysis processes by temporarily coordinating the RE3+ centers at intermediate stages of reaction and/or by affecting the local pH environment surrounding the cluster. We therefore hypothesized that target MOFs based on the RE4(μ3-OH)4(COO)6 2+ cluster should require carboxylate linkers having a primary amino group located at the ortho position to the coordinating carboxylate. To implement this design strategy, we reacted 2-amino-1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2–NH2–BDC) with GdCl3·6H2O in mixed dimethylformamide (DMF) and water solution at 100 °C. This reaction yielded clear, colorless cubic crystals, MOF-1114­(Gd).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Formation of RE4(μ3-OH)4-related complexes relies on well-controlled hydrolysis or alcoholysis of RE3+ where both solution conditions and suitable supporting ligands play essential roles. Several studies have reported the formation and crystallization of various complexes with RE4(μ3-OH)4 cores from aqueous or alcoholic solutions in the presence of a variety of α-amino acids as supporting ligands. In these examples, the α-amino groups in proximity to the coordinating carboxylates may play an important role in regulating the RE3+ hydrolysis/alcoholysis processes by temporarily coordinating the RE3+ centers at intermediate stages of reaction and/or by affecting the local pH environment surrounding the cluster. We therefore hypothesized that target MOFs based on the RE4(μ3-OH)4(COO)6 2+ cluster should require carboxylate linkers having a primary amino group located at the ortho position to the coordinating carboxylate. To implement this design strategy, we reacted 2-amino-1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2-NH2-BDC) with GdCl3⋅6H2O in mixed dimethylformamide (DMF) and water solution at 100 °C. This reaction yielded clear, colorless cubic crystals, MOF-1114(Gd).

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) of MOF-1114­(Gd) revealed that it crystallizes in the cubic space group Fm3̅m with the unit cell dimensions a = b = c = 27.860 Å. The inorganic SBU has the distorted cubane Gd4(μ3-OH)4 polymetallic core with T d symmetry (A and Figure S2.1). The four Gd3+ ions located at the vertices of the tetrahedron (shown in green in A) are bridged by four μ3-OH which protrude slightly from the four triangular faces. Each Gd3+ pair is bridged by one carboxylate group along each edge of the tetrahedron. In addition, two other O atoms are bound to each Gd3+; one is located on the 3-fold axis and the other is disordered among 3 symmetry equivalent positions around the 3-fold axis with equal 1/3 occupancy (Figure S2.1). We speculate that these O atoms could be either water molecules or μ1-OH coordinating to Gd3+ ions. The inorganic SBUs, formulated as [Gd4(μ3-OH)4(COO)6(H2O)8–x (μ1-OH) x ](2–x)+, are connected by the linear aminophenylene linkers into a pcu 3-D framework (A–C). Interconnected ∼10 Å × 10 Å 1-D channels run along the a, b, and c crystallographic axes. In addition to Gd3+, isoreticular MOFs were prepared using Y3+, Tb3+, Dy3+, Ho3+, Er3+, Tm3+, and Yb3+, as evidenced by comparing their powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns to that collected for MOF-1114­(Gd) and that simulated from single crystal diffraction data (D and Figures S2.3 to S2.10). Attempts to make isoreticular MOFs by reacting RECl3·6H2O with 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H2–BDC) or other functionalized variants of H2–BDC (e.g., −Br, −NO2, −OH) yielded MOFs containing infinite RE3+-carboxylate SBUs, pointing toward the potential importance of the primary amino group in influencing SBU formation. Collectively, this series of new MOFs represents a platform for different studies and applications based on the unique optical, magnetic, and catalytic properties of RE3+.

elements.content: MOF-1114 could be charged depending on x, the number of μ1-OH groups per SBU. For example, if x is less than 2, the framework would be positively charged. The positive charges would likely be balanced by anions, such as Cl–, randomly disordered in the MOF cavities. Qualitative scanning electron microscopy energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (SEM/EDS) analysis on the as-synthesized MOF-1114­(Tb) (Figures S2.11 to S2.16) revealed the presence of Cl in the MOF crystals, likely in the form of mobile Cl– ions, as confirmed by ion exchange experiments. MOF-1114­(Tb) was soaked in a 0.1 M DMF solution of NMe4BF4 for 5 days. Thereafter, the crystalline material was thoroughly washed with fresh DMF and analyzed using SEM/EDS, which shows nearly complete removal of Cl– and appearance of F from BF4 – (Figures S2.17 to S2.20). The number of mobile anions per formula unit in MOF-1114 was quantified by solution nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy. An ion-exchanged MOF-1114­(Tb) sample was digested with acidified DMSO-d 6 and analyzed using both solution 1H and 19F NMR with the internal standard α,α,α-trifluorotoluene (Figures S2.21 to S2.22). NMe4 + was not observed via 1H NMR, while 0.5 BF4 – per NH2–BDC were observed via 19F NMR, indicating 1.5 Cl– per SBU in the as-synthesized MOF-1114­(Tb). The as-synthesized MOF-1114 is therefore formulated as [RE4(μ3-OH)4(NH2–BDC)3(H2O)7.5(μ1-OH)0.5]·1.5Cl,10DMF according to elemental microanalysis (see page S13 in Supporting Information for details) and solution 1H NMR (Figure S2.23). We note that each MOF analogue may have elemental compositions that deviate slightly from this formula. These data indicate that (i) the framework is cationic, and (ii) the anions are mobile and can be readily exchanged without loss of framework crystallinity (Figure S2.24). Therefore, ion exchange could advantageously be used to tailor the MOF pore space and adjust MOF properties. Thermogravimetric analyses of both as-synthesized and BF4 – anion-exchanged MOF-1114­(Tb) samples (Figure S2.25) show a steep weight loss corresponding to solvent removal between 25 °C and ∼150 °C followed by a steady gradual weight loss up to 650 °C. We have not yet determined the experimental conditions for activating the as-synthesized MOF to obtain permanent porosity. However, after anion exchange with BF4 –, MOF-1114­(Tb) can be activated. Despite a loss of crystallinity after activation, N2 adsorption analysis (77 K) yields a type I isotherm (Figure S2.26), characteristic of a microporous material.

elements.content: Having successfully prepared MOF-1114 via deliberate design and directed synthesis, we next sought to build a family of isoreticular analogues using biphenyl- and terphenyl-based amino-functionalized carboxylate linkers: 3,3′-diamino-1,1′-biphenyl-4,4′-dicarboxylate (NH2–BPDC) and 3,3″-diamino-1,1′:4′,1″-terphenyl-4,4″-dicarboxylate (NH2-TPDC) (E). Using similar solvothermal conditions that yielded MOF-1114 but substituting either H2–NH2–BPDC or H2–NH2–TPDC for H2–NH2–BDC, two new 2-fold interpenetrated MOF structures were formed: MOF-1130­(Y,Gd,Tb,Dy,Ho) and MOF-1131­(Er,Yb). MOF-1130 and MOF-1131 are isoreticular. MOF-1130 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n (a = 18.0453 Å, b = 18.1800 Å, c = 32.5984 Å; α = 90°, β = 95.864°, γ = 90°); MOF-1131 crystallizes in the same space group with different unit cell dimensions (a = 23.6058 Å, b = 22.2824 Å, c = 37.1223 Å; α = 90°, β = 90.222°, γ = 90°) (F,G, Figures S3.1 to S3.10). The inorganic SBU for both MOF-1130 and MOF-1131 (E) consists of the RE4(μ3-OH)4 polymetallic core observed in MOF-1114. This result confirms our hypothesis that the primary amino group adjacent to the carboxylate facilitates formation of RE4(μ3-OH)4. However, in addition to the six carboxylates that bridge the edges of the RE3+ tetrahedron, two additional carboxylate groups coordinate in a chelating mode to two of the RE3+ in the cluster, resulting in a total of eight carboxylates per SBU present in two different coordination modes (E; O on chelating carboxylates highlighted in orange). This new SBU, formulated as [RE4(μ3-OH)4(COO)8(solvent)4] (solvent = DMF or H2O) according to SCXRD data, should be a neutral moiety, which is supported by the absence of Cl peaks in the SEM/EDS spectra (Figures S3.11 to S3.21). To visualize the crystal structures of MOF-1130 and MOF-1131, a single, noninterpenetrated framework is shown for each MOF in F and G, respectively (the interpenetrated frameworks are shown in Figure S3.1). Cages within the MOF are defined by eight neighboring inorganic SBUs that no longer sit at the corners of a cube, as in MOF-1114. Instead, the cages are distorted with two parallel faces along (010), each having one additional ligand cross-linking two SBUs on the face diagonal. The carboxylates from these diagonal cross-linkers coordinate to the single RE3+, while the carboxylates on the linkers on the edges of the cage all bridge two RE3+ ions.
elements.clean_text: Having successfully prepared MOF-1114 via deliberate design and directed synthesis, we next sought to build a family of isoreticular analogues using biphenyl- and terphenyl-based amino-functionalized carboxylate linkers: 3,3'-diamino-1,1'-biphenyl-4,4'-dicarboxylate (NH2-BPDC) and 3,3"-diamino-1,1':4',1"-terphenyl-4,4"-dicarboxylate (NH2-TPDC) (E). Using similar solvothermal conditions that yielded MOF-1114 but substituting either H2-NH2-BPDC or H2-NH2-TPDC for H2-NH2-BDC, two new 2-fold interpenetrated MOF structures were formed: MOF-1130(Y,Gd,Tb,Dy,Ho) and MOF-1131(Er,Yb). MOF-1130 and MOF-1131 are isoreticular. MOF-1130 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n (a = 18.0453 Å, b = 18.1800 Å, c = 32.5984 Å; α = 90°, β = 95.864°, γ = 90°); MOF-1131 crystallizes in the same space group with different unit cell dimensions (a = 23.6058 Å, b = 22.2824 Å, c = 37.1223 Å; α = 90°, β = 90.222°, γ = 90°) (F,G, Figures S3.1 to S3.10). The inorganic SBU for both MOF-1130 and MOF-1131 (E) consists of the RE4(μ3-OH)4 polymetallic core observed in MOF-1114. This result confirms our hypothesis that the primary amino group adjacent to the carboxylate facilitates formation of RE4(μ3-OH)4. However, in addition to the six carboxylates that bridge the edges of the RE3+ tetrahedron, two additional carboxylate groups coordinate in a chelating mode to two of the RE3+ in the cluster, resulting in a total of eight carboxylates per SBU present in two different coordination modes (E; O on chelating carboxylates highlighted in orange). This new SBU, formulated as [RE4(μ3-OH)4(COO)8(solvent)4] (solvent = DMF or H2O) according to SCXRD data, should be a neutral moiety, which is supported by the absence of Cl peaks in the SEM/EDS spectra (Figures S3.11 to S3.21). To visualize the crystal structures of MOF-1130 and MOF-1131, a single, noninterpenetrated framework is shown for each MOF in F and G, respectively (the interpenetrated frameworks are shown in Figure S3.1). Cages within the MOF are defined by eight neighboring inorganic SBUs that no longer sit at the corners of a cube, as in MOF-1114. Instead, the cages are distorted with two parallel faces along (010), each having one additional ligand cross-linking two SBUs on the face diagonal. The carboxylates from these diagonal cross-linkers coordinate to the single RE3+, while the carboxylates on the linkers on the edges of the cage all bridge two RE3+ ions.

elements.content: If the cross-linking ligands in MOF-1130 and MOF-1131 were removed and replaced with terminal aqua ligands, the resulting structures would be isoreticular to MOF-1114. In MOF-1114, the positive charges of the RE4(μ3-OH)4(COO)6 2+ cluster are balanced by μ1-OH groups bound to the RE3+ centers and Cl– ions in the cavities. MOF-1130 and MOF-1131 have a different means to achieve charge balance: two additional carboxylates bind to the inorganic SBUs. The longer biphenyl and terphenyl struts in MOF-1130 and MOF-1131 may yield void space that is sufficient to accommodate the additional diagonal cross-linking ligands that provide charge balance. We postulated that a sterically bulky ligand, such as 4,4′-(9,10-anthracenediyl)­bis­(2-aminobenzoate) (NH2-ABB) (H), may prevent the incorporation of the diagonal cross-linker and lead to the target expanded version of the pcu net. Using similar reaction conditions that produced MOF-1114, MOF-1130, and MOF-1131, H2–NH2–ABB and RECl3·6H2O were reacted to yield MOF-1115, which crystallizes in the cubic space group Fd3̅m with the unit cell dimensions a = b = c = 44.8598 Å. MOF-1115 consists of two maximally displaced interpenetrated frameworks that are isoreticular to MOF-1114 (I). Seven different RE3+ (Sm3+, Eu3+, Gd3+, Tb3+, Dy3+, Ho3+, Er3+) can form MOF-1115, as confirmed by comparing their PXRD patterns with that simulated from crystal structure data of MOF-1115­(Tb) (J and Figures S4.2 to S4.8). MOF-1115 is formulated as [RE4(μ3-OH)4(NH2-ABB)3(H2O)8]·2Cl,11.5DEF (DEF = diethylformamide) based on solution 1H and 19F NMR spectra of anion-exchanged MOF-1115­(Tb) (Figure S4.9 and S4.10) and CHN elemental microanalysis of as-synthesized MOF-1115­(Tb) (see page S56 in Supporting Information for details). In this example, we demonstrate the importance of ligand steric demand in influencing MOF topology. In summary, we have achieved, via design and rational, directed syntheses, a family of new pcu MOFs based on the RE4(μ3-OH)4(COO)6 2+ cluster.

elements.content: An ideal material for optical biological imaging should have excitation and emitting wavelengths within the biological window (vide supra). Many RE3+ emit in the NIR, yet typical MOF ligands that serve as the antennae absorb in the UV or high energy visible regions. In order to lower the excitation energy, ligands having extended π systems are often used. One common consequence of this approach is formation of lower density MOFs that have fewer RE3+ emitters per unit volume. We suggest that covalent postsynthetic modification (CPSM) of MOF linkers (antennae) is one way to systematically shift their excitation wavelengths to lower energy while maintaining a high density of RE3+ emitters.
elements.clean_text: An ideal material for optical biological imaging should have excitation and emitting wavelengths within the biological window (vide supra). Many RE3+ emit in the NIR, yet typical MOF ligands that serve as the antennae absorb in the UV or high energy visible regions. In order to lower the excitation energy, ligands having extended π systems are often used. One common consequence of this approach is formation of lower density MOFs that have fewer RE3+ emitters per unit volume. We suggest that covalent postsynthetic modification (CPSM) of MOF linkers (antennae) is one way to systematically shift their excitation wavelengths to lower energy while maintaining a high density of RE3+ emitters.

elements.content: The MOF-1114 platform is ideal for investigating this approach: (i) the amino groups can serve as sites for CPSM reactions used to extend the π system, and (ii) the pore space is sufficient for facile diffusion of precursor molecules for CPSM and for accommodating the product extended antennae. MOF-1114­(Yb) was selected because Yb3+ emits exclusively in the NIR range (λem = 940–1100 nm). We hypothesized that condensation reactions between primary amines of NH2–BDC and aromatic aldehydes would result in the expansion of the conjugated π system, leading to a red-shift of the excitation band. To test this hypothesis, colorless as-synthesized MOF-1114­(Yb) crystals were soaked in DMF solutions of either salicylaldehyde or 3-hydroxynaphthalene-2-carboxaldehyde to yield orange MOF-1114­(Yb) 1 crystals and red MOF-1114­(Yb) 2 crystals, respectively (). PXRD patterns after CPSM reactions indicate that both MOF-1114­(Yb) 1 and MOF-1114­(Yb) 2 retain their original crystallinity (Figures S5.1 and S5.2). 1H NMR of acid digested MOF samples suggested the inclusion of approximately 1 equiv of salicylaldehyde in MOF-1114­(Yb) 1 and 0.41 equiv of 3-hydroxynaphthalene-2-carboxaldehyde in MOF-1114­(Yb) 2 per NH2–BDC ligand (Figures S5.3 and S5.4). To confirm covalent attachment of the aldehydes to the framework prior to acid digestion, NaBH4 in ethanol was used to reduce the imine to the stable C–N single bond. The reduced MOF samples were then digested for 1H NMR analysis and liquid chromatography–mass spectrometry (LC–MS), which showed that ∼70% of the NH2–BDC in MOF-1114­(Yb) 1 were converted into the Schiff base product. Reduced alcohol product from salicylaldehyde and unmodified NH2–BDC were also observed, indicating the presence of free salicylaldehyde trapped in MOF pores after CPSM (Figures S5.5 and S5.6). Similarly, for MOF-1114­(Yb) 2 , 22% of the NH2–BDC were converted to a Schiff base product. Again, reduced alcohol product and unmodified NH2–BDC were observed, indicating free 3-hydroxynaphthalene-2-carboxaldehyde trapped in the MOF pores after CPSM (Figures S5.7 and S5.8).

elements.content:
Scale bars represent 100 μm in length.

Absorption spectra collected on single crystalline samples of MOF-1114­(Yb), MOF-1114­(Yb) 1 , and MOF-1114­(Yb) 2 are sequentially red-shifted. The as-synthesized MOF-1114­(Yb) only absorbs below 450 nm, while the absorption bands of MOF-1114­(Yb) 1 and MOF-1114­(Yb) 2 extend to 550 and 650 nm, respectively (A). To rule out the possibility that the red-shift of absorption bands is caused by the presence of free aldehyde molecules in the pores, solution UV–vis spectra were collected for each of the free aldehydes (B). Both molecules only absorb at wavelengths below 500 nm. Therefore, the red-shift of absorption spectra and the crystal color change after CPSM reactions can be ascribed to the imine products featuring extended conjugated π systems.

elements.content: Photoluminescence studies were then performed. The characteristic Yb3+ NIR emission band in the range 940–1100 nm due to the 2F5/2 → 2F7/2 transition can be observed for MOF-1114­(Yb), MOF-1114­(Yb) 1 and MOF-1114­(Yb) 2 upon excitation through the ligands’ bands at 380 nm (C). This is an indication that an “antenna effect” is operating between the organic sensitizers and Yb3+ for all samples: because Yb3+ does not possess an electronic level in the UV or in the visible, the sensitization of Yb3+ has to occur through the electronic levels of the chromophoric entities. The excitation spectra of MOF-1114­(Yb), MOF-1114­(Yb) 1 , and MOF-1114­(Yb) 2 upon monitoring the Yb3+ emission show sequential red-shifts, consistent with the absorption spectra (A vs D). Yb3+ emission in MOF-1114­(Yb) can only be excited by light with wavelengths shorter than 460 nm. In contrast, the excitation spectra are significantly red-shifted after CPSM to 570 nm for MOF-1114­(Yb) 1 and to 670 nm for MOF-1114­(Yb) 2 . This red-shift of excitation bands can be attributed to sensitizers with large conjugated π systems upon CPSM of RE3+-MOFs. It is worth mentioning that for MOF-1114­(Yb) 2 , the longest edge of the excitation wavelengths lies within the biological window (650–1450 nm). This advantage in combination with Yb3+ emission in the NIR range makes MOF-1114­(Yb) 2 a promising candidate for biological applications including in vivo imaging.

elements.content: Quantum yields of NIR Yb3+ emission (Q Yb) were determined under excitation at 380 and 500 nm (E). Q Yb values for MOF-1114­(Yb) 1 and MOF-1114­(Yb) 2 under 380 nm excitation were found to be similar to that of unmodified MOF-1114­(Yb). On the other hand, CPSM significantly improves Yb3+ quantum yields under higher excitation wavelength, resulting in up to 4.4 times increase compared to the unmodified MOF-1114­(Yb). Luminescence lifetimes of Yb3+ MOFs upon monitoring the 2F5/2 → 2F7/2 transition lie in the range 620–670 ns, indicating that CPSM does not significantly affect the coordination environment around Yb3+.

elements.content: We successfully designed and synthesized a new class of MOFs based on the RE4(μ3-OH)4 cluster motif. A new pcu MOF platform was created using the highly symmetric RE4(μ3-OH)4(COO)6 2+ cluster as the inorganic SBU. We demonstrated that this MOF platform is highly tunable in terms of RE3+ composition and structure metrics. It can be systematically modified via either postsynthetic anion exchange or covalent modification. Finally, CPSM was used to deliberately red-shift the excitation wavelengths of a representative NIR-emitting MOF, MOF-1114­(Yb), into the range suitable for biological imaging applications.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

We successfully designed and synthesized a new class of MOFs based on the RE4(μ3-OH)4 cluster motif. A new pcu MOF platform was created using the highly symmetric RE4(μ3-OH)4(COO)6 2+ cluster as the inorganic SBU. We demonstrated that this MOF platform is highly tunable in terms of RE3+ composition and structure metrics. It can be systematically modified via either postsynthetic anion exchange or covalent modification. Finally, CPSM was used to deliberately red-shift the excitation wavelengths of a representative NIR-emitting MOF, MOF-1114(Yb), into the range suitable for biological imaging applications.

elements.content: All purchased chemicals were used without further purification except where otherwise noted. Nanopure water (18.1 MΩ) was obtained from a Barnstead Diamond water purification system. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were collected using a Bruker AXS D8 Discover powder diffractometer at 40 kV, 40 mA for Cu Kα (λ = 1.5406 Å) with a scan speed of 0.10 s/step from 3 to 45° at a step size of 0.02°. The data were analyzed using the EVA program from the Bruker Powder Analysis Software package. The simulated powder patterns were calculated using Mercury 3.8 based on crystal structures of corresponding MOFs. Single crystal X-ray diffraction experiments were performed on a Bruker X8 Prospector Ultra diffractometer equipped with an Apex II CCD detector and an IμS microfocus Cu Kα X-ray source (λ = 1.54178 Å). Data were collected at 230 or 240 K under N2 flow and processed using the Bruker APEX II software package and refined with Olex2 program. 1H, 13C and 19F NMR spectra were obtained using Bruker Avance III 300/400/500 MHz spectrometers. Chemical shifts are in parts per million (ppm) using the residual solvent peak (CDCl3, D2O, or DMSO-d 6) as references. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed using a TGA Q500 thermal analysis system under a N2 atmosphere from room temperature to 650 °C at a ramping rate of 5 °C/min. LC–MS analyses were performed on a Shimadzu LCMS-2020 instrument using a 6 min running time with a constant 1:1 ratio of acetonitrile: water at a constant flow rate of 0.2 mL/min without passing through a column. SEM/EDS analyses were conducted using ZEISS Sigma 500 VP SEM with Oxford Aztec X-EDS. The crystal samples were washed with ethanol and drop cast on silicon wafers and dried under ambient condition before SEM/EDS analyses. Solution UV–vis absorption spectra were collected using an Agilent 8453 UV–vis spectrometer equipped with deuterium and tungsten lamps. Solid state UV–vis absorption spectra were collected on individual crystals on glass slide using a CRAIC QDI 2010 microspectrophotometer in transmission mode. The sampling area was fixed at 37 × 37 μm2. The photoluminescence properties were measured in an integration sphere using a Horiba Jobin-Yvon Fluorolog-3 spectrofluorometer equipped with a 450 W xenon excitation source and a visible photomultiplier tube (PMT) (220–800 nm, R928P; Hamamatsu), and a NIR PMT (950–1650 nm, H10330–75; Hamamatsu) on solid MOF samples stored under DMF in quartz capillary tubes. All spectra were corrected for the instrumental functions. Luminescence lifetimes were determined under 355 nm excitation provided by the third harmonic of a YG 980 Quantel Nd:YAG laser; emission signals were selected using a Horiba Scientific iHR-320 monochromator, detected using a Hamamatsu H10330–75 NIR PMT, fed into a 500 MHz bandpass digital oscilloscope (TDS 754C; Tektronix), transferred to a PC in which data were processed with the Origin 8 program. Quantum yields were determined with a Horiba Jobin-Yvon Fluorolog-3 spectrofluorimeter based on an absolute method (Model G8, GMP SA, Renens, Switzerland). Each sample was measured several times under comparable experimental conditions, varying the position of samples. Estimated experimental error for the quantum yield determination is ∼10%.

elements.content: 2-Amino-1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (1 equiv) and RECl3·6H2O (3 or 4 equiv) were dissolved by DMF in a 20 mL Pyrex vial. To the DMF solution, a certain amount of nanopure water was added. The vial was then capped and placed in a 100 °C oven for 12 h to yield cubic block crystals. Once the reaction cooled to room temperature, the mother liquor was decanted. The crystals were then washed with fresh DMF (3×). The detailed syntheses using different RECl3·6H2O can be found in the Supporting Information.
elements.clean_text:
General Synthesis of MOF-1114 

2-Amino-1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid (1 equiv) and RECl3⋅6H2O (3 or 4 equiv) were dissolved by DMF in a 20 mL Pyrex vial. To the DMF solution, a certain amount of nanopure water was added. The vial was then capped and placed in a 100 °C oven for 12 h to yield cubic block crystals. Once the reaction cooled to room temperature, the mother liquor was decanted. elements.content: Approximately 100 mg of as-synthesized MOF-1114­(Tb) crystals were soaked in 10 mL of a 0.1 M DMF solution of NMe4BF4 in a vial. The NMe4BF4 solution was removed and the crystals were washed with fresh DMF (3×) every 24 h before the vial was replenished with fresh NMe4BF4 solution. After 5 days, the crystals were copiously washed with DMF and dried on a Schlenk line before solution 1H and 19F NMR analysis. About 5 mg of crystals were dissolved in 500 μL of DMSO-d 6 and 15 μL of DCl in D2O (36%). One μL of α,α,α-trifluorotoluene was added as internal standard in the sample before 1H and 19F NMR.
elements.clean_text:
Anion Exchange of MOF-1114(Tb) with NMe4BF4 

Approximately 100 mg of as-synthesized MOF-1114(Tb) crystals were soaked in 10 mL of a 0.1 M DMF solution of NMe4BF4 in a vial. The NMe4BF4 solution was removed and the crystals were washed with fresh DMF (3×) every 24 h before the vial was replenished with fresh NMe4BF4 solution. After 5 days, the crystals were copiously washed with DMF and dried on a Schlenk line before solution 1H and 19F NMR analysis. About 5 mg of crystals were dissolved in 500 μL of DMSO-d 6 and 15 μL of DCl in D2O (36%). One μL of α,α,α-trifluorotoluene was added as internal standard in the sample before 1H and 19F NMR.

elements.content: After anion exchange, ∼50 mg of MOF-1114­(Tb) crystals were exchanged in dry EtOH for 3 days in a 20 mL vial. EtOH was removed every 24 h followed by replenishment with fresh EtOH until no DMF peak was observed by solution 1H NMR of an acid digested MOF sample. The crystals were then transferred to the activation chamber of a Tousimis SAMDRI-PVT-3B supercritical drier where supercritical CO2 activation experiment was performed. During the entire transfer process, all the crystals were soaked under dry EtOH. After cooling to 0 °C, the chamber was filled with liquid CO2. Every 30 min, the chamber was purged for 5 min, while the CO2 filling rate was kept above the purge rate to ensure that the MOF sample remains soaked under liquid CO2. The chamber temperature was kept between 0–10 °C. After 6 h, the chamber filled with liquid CO2 was heated to 40 °C to transform CO2 from liquid state to supercritical state. The chamber was then vented slowly for the next 18 h until the pressure dropped down to 1 atm. The MOF sample was then degassed at 50 °C under dynamic vacuum for 24 h before the N2 adsorption experiment was performed on a Quantachrome Autosorb-1 instrument at 77 K.
elements.clean_text:
N2 Adsorption at 77 K

After anion exchange, ~50 mg of MOF-1114(Tb) crystals were exchanged in dry EtOH for 3 days in a 20 mL vial. EtOH was removed every 24 h followed by replenishment with fresh EtOH until no DMF peak was observed by solution 1H NMR of an acid digested MOF sample. The crystals were then transferred to the activation chamber of a Tousimis SAMDRI-PVT-3B supercritical drier where supercritical CO2 activation experiment was performed. During the entire transfer process, all the crystals were soaked under dry EtOH. After cooling to 0 °C, the chamber was filled with liquid CO2. Every 30 min, the chamber was purged for 5 min, while the CO2 filling rate was kept above the purge rate to ensure that the MOF sample remains soaked under liquid CO2. The chamber temperature was kept between 0-10 °C. After 6 h, the chamber filled with liquid CO2 was heated to 40 °C to transform CO2 from liquid state to supercritical state. The chamber was then vented slowly for the next 18 h until the pressure dropped down to 1 atm. The MOF sample was then degassed at 50 °C under dynamic vacuum for 24 h before the N2 adsorption experiment was performed on a Quantachrome Autosorb-1 instrument at 77 K.

elements.content: Five mg of as-synthesized MOF-1114­(Yb) were soaked in 1 mL 0.5 M DMF solution of salicylaldehyde for 48 h at room temperature to yield orange MOF-1114­(Yb) 1 crystals. The orange crystals were then copiously washed with anhydrous DMF (5×). The MOF crystals were dried under vacuum for 10 min and dissolved in a mixture of 500 μL DMSO-d 6 and 15 μL 36% D2O solution of DCl. The solution was used for 1H NMR experiment. To confirm the formation of imine bond, MOF-1114­(Yb) 1 was then reacted with 1 mL of 0.3 M ethanol solution of NaBH4 in a 4 mL vial. After 24 h, the solid sample was washed with MeOH (3×) and dried under a Schlenk line vacuum for 10 min. To the dried crystal sample were added 500 μL D2O and 10 μL 10% D2O solution of NaOD. The mixture was sonicated for 30 min and centrifuged. The supernatant was used for 1H NMR. Three mg of the reduced product from MOF-1114­(Yb) 1 were dissolved in 1 mL MeOH and 15 μL of 36% HCl in H2O. The solution was used for LC–MS experiment.
